conclusion: To determine when the two objects meet, we need to find the time at which their positions are the same.
The position of each object as a function of time can be found by integrating the velocity function.

From the velocity-time graph: The position of object A as a function of time is given by the area under the curve for A. The position of object B as a function of time is given by the area under the curve for B.
The area under the curve for A from t = 0 to t = t is represented as s_A(t) = ∫_0^t v_A(t') dt', where v_A(t) is the velocity of object A as a function of time.
The area under the curve for B from t = 0 to t = t is represented as s_B(t) = ∫_0^t v_B(t') dt', where v_B(t) is the velocity of object B as a function of time.
The objects meet when s_A(t) = s_B(t).
By examining the graph, the areas under the curves for A and B are equal at t = t_3.
The areas are the same up to t = t_3, and after t = t_3, the area under the curve for B starts to exceed the area under the curve for A.
Therefore, the two objects meet at t = t_3.
